awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Impact of a colloidal suspension droplet: suspension flows at extreme shear rates
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
An impacting liquid drop is not only an eye-catching phenomenon, it is also an ideal testbed for studying material properties.  This is due to the high speed at which an impacting drop spreads out (up to 10 m/s); this spreading process has been carefully studied in ordinary fluids, but little work has been done to understand how this impact behavior is modified in a complex fluid.  Complex fluids such as ketchup, paint, and oobleck (cornstarch-in-water) have the property that their viscosity (resistance to flow) depends on the applied stress.  Thus, these fluids flow quite differently depending on the stress they experience.  This research project explores how this stress-dependent viscosity alters drop-impact behavior.  Complex fluids are ubiquitous, and a deeper understanding of their behavior in impact processes is essential to industries such as food and drug processing, additive manufacturing, and printing/coating. In addition to the research synergy between PI Driscoll and Co-PI Cheng, the collaboration allows a unique opportunity for expanding students’ training:  a personnel exchange has been implemented, so that the students involved in the project spend two weeks each year at their non-home institution. This personnel exchange provides trainees opportunities to connect with a larger network of scientists, as well as the experience of another discipline and institution. Additionally, the research team leverages the stunning and eye-catching phenomena of drop impact to design demos to educate the broader public about the fascinating properties of complex fluids. 

Technical Abstract:
Liquid drop impact is a classic problem in fluid mechanics and soft materials and has been studied extensively for many decades. In comparison, studies focusing on the impact of non-Newtonian fluid droplets, particularly suspension droplets, have been few and far between, even though such processes are essential in industries such as food and drug processing, additive manufacturing, and printing/coating. This project addresses this knowledge gap by conducting an extensive study of impacting colloidal suspension droplets, providing a full understanding of the dynamics of suspension-drop impact and drawing a direct comparison between Newtonian and non-Newtonian drop impact processes. This systematic study varies control parameters such as suspension volume fraction, particle shape, impact energy, and target size.  Using both advanced imaging techniques, as well as new tools to measure impact forces and stress distributions, the team aims to fully characterize both the kinematics and dynamics of impacting suspension droplets. Suspension-drop impact provides an ideal model system to probe suspension dynamics under complex and extreme conditions: a spreading droplet generates shear rates at least an order of magnitude higher than those that are accessible via standard rheometry. In addition, the isolated air-fluid interface in drop impact imposes a unique open boundary rarely seen in other circumstances. Thus, this project provides crucial missing information on suspension dynamics under extreme conditions, complementary to the current understanding of suspension flows obtained in conventional bulk rheological tests.

This Division of Materials Research (DMR) grant supports research to study impacting colloidal suspension droplets between Newtonian and non-Newtonian drop impact processes with funding from the Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Program in DMR of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS) Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From raindrops battering on a windshield to coffee drops splashing on a dining table, the impact of liquid drops on a solid substrate is a ubiquitous daily-life fluid phenomenon, relevant to a large number of natural, environmental and industrial processes. Although drop impact has been studied for over a century since the pioneering work of Worthington, most of the existing research focused on the impact of drops made of simple Newtonian liquids such as water. The current understanding of the impact of drops of non-Newtonian fluids, i.e., fluids with variable stress-dependent viscosity, is still rudimentary, even though such a process is essential for many important industrial practices ranging from food and drug processing, to additive manufacturing, and to printing and coating. By combining experiments, simulations and theory, we investigated the dynamics of drop impact of non-Newtonian fluids in this project and filled in the knowledge gap. In particular, we experimentally studied the impact of cornstarch-water mixtures---a paradigmatic example of shear-thickening fluid---and examined the correlation between the rheology of the fluid and its impact dynamics over a large parameter space. We also developed a numerical algorithm to simulate the impact of generic non-Newtonian fluids with different viscosity-stress dependence.

We have made two significant findings in this project. First, in collaboration with the Driscoll group at Northwestern University, we provided a comprehensive understanding of the impact dynamics of shear-thickening fluids. In particular, through a systematic measurement of the impact force of cornstarch-water mixtures under different impact conditions, our experiments illustrated two different transitions in the dynamics of impacting drops. At low impact velocities, we identified a transition from a liquid-like impact behavior to a solid-like impact behavior as we increased either particle concentration or the impact velocity of drops. At high impact velocities, we observed an unexpected reverse transition from a solid-like impact behavior to a liquid-like impact behavior as we increased the impact velocity of drops. We further showed that these transitions in impact behaviors are correlated with the rheological response of cornstarch mixtures. As such, our study provided not only a detailed understanding of the impact dynamics of shear-thickening fluids over a wide range of parameters but also new insights into the rheology of cornstarch-water mixtures at extremely high shear rates beyond the range of conventional rheometry.

Second, we have numerically explored the impact dynamics of generic non-Newtonian fluids. Specifically, we have developed a numerical algorithm to simulate the impact of non-Newtonian fluids based on the Carreau fluid model. The model allowed us to examine the dependence of drop-impact dynamics on various non-Newtonian parameters such as the ratio of the low-shear-rate to the high-shear-rate viscosity, the critical transition shear rate, and the steepness of viscosity change. We are particularly interested in how the maximum spreading diameter and the maximum impact force vary with these parameters. Our work shed light onto the general principles governing the impact of non-Newtonian fluid drops and provided useful guidelines for designing non-Newtonian fluids with targeted drop impact dynamics. 

Our work has led to one publication in a high-profile journal Nature Communications, which has already accumulated 28 citations by the end of the project. Two more manuscripts are currently under preparation for publication. A PhD thesis has also been published based on the results of the project. Our group has given 3 talks in conferences and seminars on the project, which disseminated the results of the project in relevant academic and industrial communities. The grant supported two graduate students including one female student, one of whom has graduated with PhD and is now a research engineer in the semiconductor industry. Moreover, we have recruited two undergraduate students including one female student from the University of Minnesota (UMN) for the project. During the project, we facilitated student exchange between the two research groups of this collaborative project. A chemical engineering student from UMN visited Northwestern University (NU), while a physics student from NU visited UMN. The exchange activity provided excellent opportunities for training and professional development of the graduate students and allowed them to experience research cultures in different disciplines.  In terms of education, the results of the project provided raw materials for the PI for his lecture on spray coating in the summer course of coating and printing, which has been held annually since the start of the project. The results of the project also stimulated an ongoing collaboration between PI’s lab and the PPG company for developing paints and coating materials. In terms of outreach, the PI has served as the faculty mentor of the energy club at UMN during the period of the project, which promoted the energy awareness in the local communities of Twin Cities.
